user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1ProcessMessageBlock:
```c
static void
SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (struct SHA1Context *context)
{
  const uint32_t K[] = { 0x5A827999, 0x6ED9EBA1, 0x8F1BBCDC, 0xCA62C1D6 };
  int i;
  uint32_t temp;
  uint32_t W[80];
  uint32_t A, B, C, D, E;

  for (i = 0; i < 16; i++)
  {
    W[i] = ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4]) << 24;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 1]) << 16;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 2]) << 8;
    W[i] |= context->message_block[i * 4 + 3];
  }
  for (i = 16; i < 80; i++)
  {
    W[i]
      = SHA1CircularShift (1, W[i - 3] ^ W[i - 8] ^ W[i - 14] ^ W[i - 16]);
  }
  A = context->intermediate_hash[0];
  B = context->intermediate_hash[1];
  C = context->intermediate_hash[2];
  D = context->intermediate_hash[3];
  E = context->intermediate_hash[4];
  for (i = 0; i < 20; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | ((~B) & D)) + E + W[i]
           + K[0];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 20; i < 40; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[1];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 40; i < 60; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | (B & D) | (C & D)) + E
           + W[i] + K[2];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 60; i < 80; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[3];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  context->intermediate_hash[0] += A;
  context->intermediate_hash[1] += B;
  context->intermediate_hash[2] += C;
  context->intermediate_hash[3] += D;
  context->intermediate_hash[4] += E;
  context->message_block_index = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided function. The code uses only standard C constructs: a static function definition, a struct pointer parameter, stdint.h types (uint32_t), array initialiser with implicit size (const uint32_t K[] = {...}), ordinary arrays and indexing, for-loops, bitwise/shift operators, and ordinary function calls (SHA1CircularShift). There are no compiler-specific keywords or built-ins (for example no __attribute__, __asm__, __typeof__, __builtin_*, no inline assembly, no GCC/Clang/MSC extensions), no variable-length arrays with non-constant sizes, no designated initializers, and no C++-only constructs. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions). If your toolchain documents any of the used identifiers/types (e.g. uint32_t or SHA1CircularShift) as non-standard extensions, those should be reported, but based on standard C and typical C library headers nothing in this function is a language extension.
